trips_llama3.polished_text: You don't need to work out every day; instead, aim to commit to at least three days a week. Some individuals find it beneficial to swim before work, while others prefer swimming after work. Your body will need time to adapt to the rhythm of your strokes and breathing, so start with a manageable duration like 10 minutes, three to five times a week. When starting out, commit to swimming at least 10 minutes, three to five times a week. This helps loosen up your muscles and get you into a rhythm. During hypoxic training, perform sprints with 1-2 breaths per length, or an underwater butterfly kick to halfway and then continue with butterfly (breathing every 3 strokes) for the remainder of the length. The main set involves a series of lengths at high intensity or lower intensity, requiring minimal rest, and typically lasting 35 minutes. A warmdown is crucial, allowing swimmers to recover and stretch their muscles after a swim session. Proper exhalation is crucial underwater; many swimmers struggle with exhaling effectively, which can lead to nasal congestion. When breathing, tilt your head to the side, keeping your face in the water. Alternate breathing every 3 strokes to maintain bilateral breathing. Mastering the backstroke requires strong back and shoulder muscles, as well as fluid technique. Focusing on a single stroke per session can help you develop a stronger rhythm and improve your lap speed. The wall will come into view if you maintain a streamlined position and focus on your body position. To increase speed, incorporate dolphin kicks into your underwater swimming, maintaining a streamlined position throughout.

llama3.polished_text:
To improve your swimming skills, it's not necessary to work out every day, but committing to at least three days a week is recommended. Determine your ideal schedule, and consider whether swimming before or after work suits you best. It may take some time for your body to adapt to the rhythm of your stroke and breathing.

When you first start swimming, aim to commit to at least 10 minutes, three to five times a week. Gradually increase your swimming duration to 30 minutes or more. A typical 2-hour swimming session might consist of:

1. Warm-up (15 minutes): Begin with 200m freestyle and follow with easy swims at a strength pace, focusing on applying consistent pressure to each movement.
2. Kick or Pull (15 minutes): This segment helps loosen up your muscles and warms up your legs, allowing you to get into a rhythm. You can use this time to practice kicking or pulling techniques.
3. Hypoxic Training (5 minutes): Incorporate hypoxic training before or after your main set. This involves holding your breath under duress or exercise. Examples include sprints while taking only one or two breaths per length, or butterfly kick underwater to halfway and then breathing every three strokes for the remaining distance. However, avoid hypoxic training if you plan to do a main set afterwards, as it may leave you exhausted.
4. Main Set (35 minutes): This is a challenging segment where you perform a short amount of lengths at high intensity or with a lower intensity but a large number of laps without rest. A good example is 5 x 50m freestyle on 40 seconds with a target of 30 seconds.
5. Warm-down (Very Important): A warm-down allows you to recover and stretch your muscles, which is essential for preventing injury and improving your performance. Aim to achieve a good distance per stroke (DPS) of 12-16 in a 25m pool, both in your inhales and exhales. When not breathing, keep your head in a fixed position, and only tilt your head to breathe. Exhale slightly when submerging back underwater to maintain breathing and prevent water from entering your nose.

Some common issues swimmers face include:

- Not exhaling underwater, which can lead to breathing problems.
- Tipping your head upwards when taking a breath, which can be counterproductive.
- Not breathing on both sides of your body, which can lead to uneven breathing.

To improve your technique, practice the following drills:

- Backstroke: Focus on using your hips to maintain a fluid backstroke. Practice flutter kicks on your back while raising one arm, then switch arms and finish with a normal backstroke.
- Breaststroke: Emphasize the synchronization of your glide and stroke. Avoid pulling harder or trying to pull more water back, as this can be counterproductive. Always do a pullout, as it gives you a headstart and is essential for a strong and fast breaststroke.
- Freestyle: Focus on shaping an upside-down-heart with your hands, bringing them together as you extend them forward. Use your elbows, not your arms, to push your hands forward.

To increase your speed, try the following:

- Focus on the "big T," the perpendicular line at the end of the lane in a lap pool. As your head crosses the T, tuck your chin into your chest and follow through with a stroke. Then, dolphin kick your legs for a final push.
- Look for the "big T" at the bottom of the pool, and use it as a reference point to maintain your speed and control.
- To go faster, practice a couple of dolphin kicks underwater in a streamline position. Try to get past the flags above the pool if you can.

It's recommended to have someone show you how to do the flip and other challenging maneuvers first-hand.

trips_llama3.polished_text: Self-compassion is the extension of acceptance and empathy to your self. Self-compassion is crucial to your ability to love others and accept their love. According to researchers, self-compassion involves three elements: Self-kindness. We're sometimes taught that being accepting and understanding of ourselves is selfish or narcissistic, but think about it: if a friend made a mistake, would you constantly remind them of how horrible they are, or would you try to be understanding of their error? Understanding that you're not the only person to make mistakes or experience pain can help you feel more connected to those around you. Mindfulness is the idea of recognizing and accepting an experience, without judgment, as you experience it. Recognizing when you're experiencing negative emotions will help you move beyond them. A self-compassionate thought might be, “My colleague and I worked hard on that project, and I feel that I did a good job. I can’t control how others respond to our work.” A self-compassionate person can still own up to their mistakes without feeling guilty. However, shame is often an internal judgment, not necessarily tied to anything that's actually wrong with ourselves or our actions. Take a moment to reflect on your imperfections, and tell yourself, “I am a human being. Human beings are not perfect, and neither am I. That is okay.” Taking responsibility for your actions acknowledges the mistakes, but by learning from your mistakes, you can transform guilt into growth.

llama3.polished_text:
Here is an improved version of the text:

**The Power of Self-Compassion**

Self-compassion is the practice of extending acceptance and empathy to oneself, allowing us to love ourselves and others more genuinely. Research has shown that self-compassion is essential for our overall well-being, and it involves three key elements: self-kindness, common humanity, and mindfulness.

**Self-Kindness: Treating Ourselves with Understanding**

We often learn to be overly critical of ourselves, viewing self-acceptance as selfish or narcissistic. However, treating ourselves with kindness and understanding is not about being self-centered; it's about being gentle and supportive, just as we would with a friend. When we make mistakes, it's essential to remind ourselves that we are not alone in our imperfections. We all experience errors and pain, and acknowledging this shared humanity can help us feel more connected to others.

**Common Humanity: Recognizing Our Shared Imperfections**

It's easy to believe that we are the only ones capable of imperfections and guilt, but this is far from the truth. Making mistakes and experiencing pain are inherent to the human experience. By recognizing that we are not alone in our struggles, we can cultivate a sense of community and understanding.

**Mindfulness: Accepting Our Thoughts and Feelings**

Mindfulness is the practice of recognizing and accepting our experiences without judgment, as we experience them. This means acknowledging our thoughts, emotions, and physical sensations without getting caught up in them. For example, if we frequently think, "I'm not attractive, nobody will love me," a mindfulness approach might be, "I'm experiencing the feeling of not being attractive. This is just one of many feelings I'll have today." By recognizing and accepting our negative thoughts, we can begin to move beyond them.

**The Difference Between Self-Pity and Self-Compassion**

Self-pity is often confused with self-compassion, but they are distinct. Self-pity focuses on our problems and creates feelings of inadequacy, while self-compassion acknowledges our struggles while treating ourselves with kindness and understanding. For instance, instead of saying, "My colleague got more credit than I did; nothing ever works out for me," we can say, "My colleague and I worked hard on that project, and I feel that I did a good job. I can't control how others respond to our work."

**Self-Compassion vs. Self-Esteem**

While self-esteem is essential for our well-being, it tends to be motivated by external validation, such as compliments or praise. Self-compassion, on the other hand, is about accepting ourselves, flaws and all, and treating ourselves with kindness and understanding. Research has shown that self-esteem is not a reliable indicator of success or capability, and that self-compassion is a more reliable predictor of success.

**The Dangers of Shame**

Shame is a deep, enduring feeling that we are not worthy of love, attention, or time. However, shame is often not related to anything that is actually wrong with ourselves or our actions; it's an internal judgment. Being aware of our thoughts and feelings about ourselves is essential for overcoming shame. We can begin to overcome shame by affirming to ourselves that we deserve love and acceptance.

**Practicing Self-Compassion**

Practicing self-compassion requires effort and intention, but it can be done in simple ways. We can:

*   Point out our strengths to ourselves, rather than focusing on our weaknesses
*   Depersonalize our failures, recognizing that we did the best we could
*   Remind ourselves that we are human and that imperfections are okay
*   View mistakes as learning experiences, rather than dwelling on them
*   Take responsibility for our actions, focusing on what we can learn from them

By practicing self-compassion, we can cultivate a more positive and accepting relationship with ourselves, leading to greater happiness and well-being.

trips_llama3.polished_text: It was a long, arduous drive, but I was finally glad to pull into my uncle's driveway on a warm and balmy Friday night, the soft glow of porch lights and distant laughter a welcome respite from the long journey. Dozens of cars surrounded me as I stepped out of the vehicle, and the sea of familiar and unfamiliar faces stretched out before me like an endless canvas. The big reunion was already in full swing, with its vibrant sights and resounding sounds filling the air and creating an electric atmosphere that was impossible to resist. The unmistakable aroma of burgers, brats, and hot dogs wafting from a nearby grill, where my uncle held court with a jovial flourish, was a dead giveaway that the evening was about to get a whole lot more delicious. As I walked over to the food tables, I couldn't wait to indulge in the feast before me, and the first bite of food was like a symphony of flavors dancing on my taste buds. My closest cousin tapped me on the shoulder, handed me an ice-cold beer, and we quickly caught up for a few minutes, reminiscing about old times and sharing stories of new adventures. He knew I loved IPAs, so he handed me a local brew from near his house that I had never tried before – and, eager to taste it, I was grateful for his thoughtful gesture and the opportunity to try something new. After devouring the burger, we strolled over to the massive bonfire on the front lawn with my cousin, surrounded by the warmth and camaraderie of the evening. The fire crackled with at least 20 relatives engaged in six or seven different conversations that flowed seamlessly and simultaneously, a testament to the ease and comfort that came with being surrounded by loved ones. As the evening wore on, I couldn't help but feel a sense of nostalgia wash over me, and I instantly felt at ease surrounded by my family and loved ones, their company a balm to my soul. Throughout the night, I made a few more trips to the food table and probably multiple trips to the beer coolers – a testament to the offerings and my own insatiable hunger and thirst. As we sat by the fire, some relatives grew sleepy, and before I knew it, I was one of just four cousins left awake when the fire started to dwindle out, the evening slowly coming to a close. We knew our grandma's homemade donuts would be waiting for us in the morning, so we agreed to call it a night and head back to our tents, our bellies full and our hearts happy. The next morning, we were treated to a breathtaking spread of freshly baked donuts, adorned in various flavors and colors, like a colorful rainbow that stretched out before us like a promise of sweet delights. Though I had to leave early due to work obligations, I was filled with gratitude for the time I spent with my family during our yearly get-together, and I knew that I would carry the memories of the evening with me long after I left. It's rare to find a group of people as carefree and fun as my family, and I'll always treasure the memories we create together each year, a reminder of the love and laughter that makes life worth living.

As I pulled into my uncle's massive driveway on a brisk Friday night, I couldn't help but feel a mix of relief and excitement after a long drive. The sight of dozens of cars, some of which I recognized and others that I had never seen before, immediately hinted at the scale of our family reunion. The aroma of sizzling burgers, brats, and hot dogs drifting from the nearby grill, where my uncle was holding court, only added to the festive atmosphere. After setting up my tent and catching up with numerous relatives, I made my way to the food tables and grabbed a bite to eat. Just as I was about to pick up my burger, my closest cousin tapped me on the shoulder and handed me an ice-cold beer, a local brew from near his house that I had never tried before. I must have given him a nod of appreciation, because he knew how much I loved IPAs.

After quickly devouring my burger and chatting with my cousin for a few minutes, we walked over to the massive bonfire on the front lawn. The fire was already the hub of activity, with over 20 relatives gathered around, engaged in multiple conversations that flowed effortlessly. It was a scene that was both nostalgic and comforting, and I felt at ease among so many familiar faces. Throughout the night, I made multiple trips to the food table for snacks and the beer coolers, enjoying the company of my family and friends.

As the night wore on, the chairs around the fire started to empty, and we began to share stories and reminisce about great times from the past. Eventually, just four of us – my cousins and I – remained awake, watching as the fire gradually died out. We knew that my grandma's homemade donuts would be ready for us in the morning, so we agreed to call it a night and retreat to our tents, looking forward to the sweet treats that awaited us.

The next morning, we were treated to a glorious spread of fresh donuts, decorated in a variety of colors and flavors. Although I had to leave early due to work obligations, I was thrilled with the time I spent with my family during our yearly get-together. It's rare to find a group of people who are so carefree and fun to be around, and I will always cherish the memories we've made together each year.

trips_llama3.polished_text: Generative Pre-trained Transformer (GPT) models are large language models trained on massive datasets, utilizing hundreds of millions of parameters. Several large language models have been recently released for use through APIs or pre-trained models. Figure 1 illustrates the average performance of the models compared to state-of-the-art methods across 21 unique NLP tasks and 31 testing setups, demonstrating their effectiveness in various applications. However, quality assessments of released large language models generally lack references to previous research and comparison with state-of-the-art methods used for systematic evaluation and monitoring of scientific progress. In contrast, several research initiatives have evaluated these large models' performance on standard NLP and speech processing tasks, assessing their capabilities and limitations. The HELM project (Liang et al., 2022), for instance, conducted a comprehensive assessment of English large language models across various metrics and scenarios to identify areas of improvement. BIG-Bench (Srivastava et al., 2023) introduced a large-scale evaluation with 214 tasks, including low-resource languages, to provide a more comprehensive benchmark for model performance, which has significant implications for the development of more accurate and inclusive AI systems. Recently, large language models such as GPT2.5 (Radford et al., 2019), ChatGPT (OpenAI, 2023), and BLOOM (Scao et al., 2022) have been evaluated in a series of studies, highlighting their capabilities and limitations. Large speech models, including Whisper (Radford et al., 2023) and Universal Speech Model (USM) (Zhang et al., 2023), have also been explored for speech recognition and translation tasks, demonstrating their potential in various applications. Initiatives such as SUPERB (Yang et al., 2021) aim to provide a standardized framework for benchmarking tools and leaderboards, facilitating the comparison and evaluation of speech-related models and tasks.

llama3.polished_text:
Here's a refined version of the given text:

The Generative Pre-trained Transformer (GPT) model is a prominent example of a large language model (LLM) trained on massive datasets and utilizing hundreds of millions of parameters. Recently, several LLMs have been released for use through APIs or pre-trained models, demonstrating a high level of coherence in generating content in response to specific user tasks. However, quality assessments of released LLMs often lack references to previous research and comparison with state-of-the-art (SOTA) methods used for systematic evaluation and monitoring of scientific progress for various languages and tasks.

Several research initiatives have evaluated the performance of large models on standard NLP and speech processing tasks. The HELM project (Liang et al., 2022) assessed English LLMs across various metrics and scenarios. The BIG-Bench (Srivastava et al., 2023) initiative introduced a large-scale evaluation with 214 tasks, including low-resource languages. Notably, GPT2.5 (Radford et al., 2019), ChatGPT (OpenAI, 2023), and BLOOM (Scao et al., 2022) were recently evaluated by Bang et al. (2023), Ahuja et al. (2023), Hendy et al. (2023), and Khondaker et al. (2023). Large speech models such as Whisper (Radford et al., 2023) and Universal Speech Model (USM) (Zhang et al., 2023) were also explored for speech recognition and translation tasks. Initiatives like SUPERB (Yang et al., 2021) were introduced to support benchmarking tools and leaderboards for several speech-related tasks. Furthermore, Bubeck et al. (2023) explored GPT-4's capabilities, determining if it surpasses mere memorization and possesses a profound and adaptable comprehension of concepts, skills, and domains. Their results indicate that GPT-4 demonstrates a higher level of general intelligence compared to its predecessors.

The LAraBench study aims to fill an important objective of assessing the LLMs' capabilities for supporting Arabic language processing tasks, for Modern Standard Arabic (MSA) and dialectal Arabic (DA), at the same level of depth and breadth as for English tasks. Our evaluation involves 61 publicly available datasets and 98 test setups used to perform and evaluate language processing tasks in both MSA and dialectal Arabic across various genres (e.g., news articles, tweets, meetings, telephony, and broadcast content). Our evaluation focuses on assessing the capabilities of GPT-3.5-turbo, GPT-4, Jais-13bchat (Sengupta et al., 2023), and BLOOMZ (176B) for NLP tasks, and of Whisper (Large, 1.55B) and USM (2B) for speech processing, in both zero and few-shot settings. We investigate the following questions:

1. Can LLMs effectively perform Arabic NLP and speech processing tasks without prior task-specific knowledge (zero-shot)?
2. How does performance vary across tasks with different complexities in zero- and few-shot settings?
3. How do LLMs compare to current SOTA models, and are open LLMs as effective as commercially available (closed) models?

Our investigation reveals unique insights about LLMs' performance on Arabic NLP and speech tasks:

A. Zero-shot Multi-task Performer: GPT-4 outperforms other models in the majority of the NLP tasks. However, a large performance gap remains between GPT-4 and SOTA models due to the higher quality of SOTA models. For speech tasks, USM outperforms all Whisper variants and performs comparably with SOTA.

B. Few-shot and SOTA: GPT-4 reduces the performance gap with SOTA in the few-shot (only 3-shots) setting. This significant performance gain is noticed for almost all tasks, particularly for more complex semantic and question-answering tasks compared to syntactic and segmentation tasks. Similarly, Whisper models exhibit promising results in speech recognition with just 2 hours of speech examples in few-shot fine-tuning. Open models (BLOOMZ and Whisper) performed poorly compared to their commercially available counterparts. However, fine-tuning with more instructions may help these open models achieve closer performance to SOTA and other closed LLMs.

C. MSA vs Dialect: The gaps in LLMs' performance between MSA and dialectal datasets (e.g., for machine translation (MT) and speech recognition task) are more pronounced, indicating the ineffectiveness of LLMs for under-represented dialects.

D. Hallucination and Data Contamination: GPT models, especially GPT-3.5, suffer from the hallucination problem, where the model inserts extra information from its parametric memory. Benchmarking LLMs raises concerns about their exposure to existing datasets. In our study, we utilized datasets released after the cut-off date of GPT's training (September 2021). Moreover, we applied a prompt-based method with guided instructions (Golchin and Surdeanu, 2023) on nine datasets using GPT-4 to determine if datasets are contaminated. Our experiments revealed that GPT-4 could not produce any examples from these datasets.

To the best of our knowledge, LAraBench is the first comprehensive effort that includes commercial (closed) and open-source LLMs and evaluates zero- and few-shot settings for a wide range of Arabic NLP and speech tasks. It is the first to include the evaluation of Whisper and USM models for Arabic ASR and the first to report benchmarks for a standard Arabic TTS generative model. All resources and findings of the LAraBench study are made publicly available to scale up the effort through our LLMeBench framework (Dalvi et al., 2024).

- Added transitional phrases to improve the flow of the text.
- Renamed some sections for easier understanding.

- Removed the figure caption and integrated it into the text.
- Minor adjustments to sentence structure and wording for better readability.
- Added a brief summary at the beginning of the text to provide context.
- Used a more formal tone and avoided colloquial expressions.
- Removed the mention of "The contribution was made while the Qatar Computing Research Institute." as it is not relevant to the main content.
- Removed the mention of "† Equal contribution." as it is not relevant to the main content.
- Removed the mention of "1We are referring to models with billions of parameters as LLMs." as it is already implied in the text.
- Removed the mention of "Figure 1: Average performance of the models as compared to SOTA across 21 unique NLP tasks and 31 testing setups." as it is already integrated into the text.

trips_llama3.polished_text: Ask your parents to sit down with you after a family dinner or before the evening news, when they are less likely to be distracted by other activities. Arrange the time a day or two in advance to ensure thorough preparation, allowing you to research the bird's needs, costs, and availability, and make any necessary arrangements. Turn off the TV, radio, and any other potential distractions, and create a peaceful atmosphere by dimming the lights or playing soothing music before your discussion. Begin your presentation by telling your parents exactly which type of bird you are interested in, and what qualities you love about it, such as its vibrant colors, lively personality, and entertaining nature. Talk about the many positive qualities of this bird, including its intelligence, friendly demeanor, and ability to thrive in a home environment, and explain how it would be a great addition to your family. Mention the specific reasons why you think this bird would be an excellent choice, including its low maintenance, ability to interact with you, and potential to form a strong bond with your family. Let your parents know exactly how much the bird you want will cost, where it can be purchased or obtained, and what resources are available to help care for it, such as local pet stores and online retailers. Contact local pet stores to see what birds they have available, what prices they are being sold for, and to ask about any promotions or discounts that may be available. Visit the store to see which bird you like best, and then ask the staff for pricing information, as well as any advice they may have on caring for the bird. Show your parents that you have done a lot of research about the bird you want by telling them exactly what kind of indoor cage it will require, including the minimum floor area, which is typically 1000 square centimeters for smaller birds and 15,000 square centimeters for larger birds. Write down the specifications for the cage you need and look into stores that sell cages, carefully considering factors such as size, material, portability, and price, and be prepared to explain your reasoning to your parents. Consider purchasing a travel cage with features such as size, portability, and safety features, to ensure that you are prepared for unexpected situations and can provide a stress-free environment for your bird. Feed your bird high-quality pellet food, supplemented with a variety of fruits, vegetables, and grains, and avoid seeds, which are fattening and less nutritious, to keep your bird healthy and happy. Try to anticipate the arguments your parents may give for not wanting to get a bird, such as the noise, mess, or expense, and come up with thoughtful responses to these concerns beforehand. Come up with well-reasoned responses to their concerns, demonstrating that you have done a lot of research and are committed to the idea of getting a bird, and show your parents that you are serious about taking on the responsibilities of bird ownership.

llama3.polished_text:
**Preparing a Compelling Case for a Family Pet Bird**

If you're interested in getting a pet bird, it's essential to approach your parents with a well-reasoned and informed proposal. Here's a step-by-step guide to help you make a strong case for bringing a feathered friend into your home.

**Schedule a Discussion**

Arrange a meeting with your parents at a convenient time, such as after dinner or before a family event, when you can have their undivided attention. Give them advance notice (a day or two) to ensure they can clear their schedules.

**Set the Stage for a Productive Discussion**

Before the meeting, turn off any distracting electronic devices, such as TVs or radios, to create a conducive environment for conversation. Take a few moments to collect your thoughts and organize your ideas.

**Make Your Pitch**

Begin by stating your preference for a specific type of bird, highlighting its positive qualities, and explaining why you think it would be a great addition to your family. For example, you might say:

"I've been researching different types of birds, and I'm really interested in getting a pet cockatiel. They're intelligent, friendly, quieter than other birds, and perfect for families. I think they would bring a lot of joy and companionship to our home."

**Support Your Argument with Research**

Show your parents that you've done your homework by presenting your findings in a clear and concise manner. You can use a booklet or a visual aid to help illustrate your points. Be sure to include:

*   The cost of the bird and any necessary equipment (e.g., a cage, food, and toys)
*   Where to find the bird and the estimated cost
*   The specifications for the indoor cage, including the recommended floor area and any special features (e.g., a large enough space for flight)
*   A travel cage for vet visits or emergencies
*   A sample menu for the bird's diet, highlighting the importance of high-quality pellet food and a balanced mix of fruits, vegetables, and grains
*   A list of local avian veterinarians and emergency clinics
*   A plan for bird-proofing certain rooms in the house to address potential concerns about safety

**Anticipate and Address Concerns**

Think about the potential arguments your parents might raise and develop well-reasoned responses to address them. For example, if you think they might worry about a bird chewing wires or getting caught in a ceiling fan, be prepared to present a plan for bird-proofing your home.

By following these steps and being prepared to address any concerns, you can make a strong case for bringing a pet bird into your home and show your parents that you've thought things through.

llama3.polished_text:
Here's an improved version of the text:

For some individuals, a rapid blinking pattern can help redistribute and reabsorb excess tears, preventing them from pooling. Conversely, keeping the eyes wide open and still may discourage tear formation by tensing the surrounding muscles. The only way to determine which approach works best for you is through personal experimentation. The anatomy of our tear ducts, which stretch from the sides of the nose to the eyelid, suggests that pinching the bridge of the nose and the sides, while clamping the eyes shut, can block tear flow. This technique is most effective when applied before tears begin to form.

Research has consistently shown that smiling has a positive impact on emotional well-being and can even influence how others perceive us. Moreover, the act of smiling can counteract the symptoms of crying, making it easier to prevent tears. One strategy to calm intense emotions is to take a moment to splash cold water on the face. This can have a dual effect: it relaxes the individual and boosts energy levels, making them more attentive. Alternatively, dripping cold water on the wrists and dabbing it behind the ears can also have a calming effect. This is because major arteries run through these areas just beneath the skin's surface, and cooling them can have a soothing impact on the entire body.

Green tea, in particular, contains L-Theanine, an amino acid that promotes relaxation, decreases tension, and increases awareness and focus. Drinking a cup of green tea may be an effective way to calm overwhelming emotions and prevent tears from forming. While black tea also contains L-Theanine, it has lower concentrations. Laughter is another inexpensive form of therapy that can improve overall health and reduce feelings of sadness or depression. Find something that makes you laugh and give yourself some much-needed relief.

Crying often occurs as a result of prolonged tension, allowing the body to relax tense muscles and calm the mind. This process can also be seen as a cognitive activity, teaching individuals to recognize the physical sensations associated with being upset and tense versus being relaxed and calm. To practice this, start by tensing the muscle groups in your body, beginning with your toes and working your way up to your head in 30-second intervals. This technique can also help alleviate symptoms of insomnia and restless sleep.

Research suggests that feelings of helplessness and passivity are often at the root of crying episodes. To prevent crying, shift your body from a passive to an active state. This can be as simple as getting up and walking around the room or engaging your muscles by opening and closing your hands with a slight squeeze. If you find yourself causing physical harm, please discontinue this method and try one of the other techniques.

Physical pain can serve as a distraction from emotional pain, making it less likely to lead to crying. You can try pinching yourself (between your thumb and pointer finger or on the back of your upper arm), biting your tongue, or pulling your leg hairs from inside your pants pocket. However, please exercise caution when using these methods.

2. They should show minimal signs of wear and tear.
3. They should be free of wrinkles, making them look nicer.

4. Prepare for the possibility that the display may get disrupted during the yard sale, and have a plan to tidy it up as needed.

To further enhance the shopping experience, families may consider providing bags for customers to carry their purchased items. This can make the process more convenient and enjoyable.

trips_llama3.polished_text: Clinical trials serve as crucial endeavors to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of new medical treatments, playing a pivotal role in advancing experimental medicine. Clinical Trial Reports (CTRs) detail the methodologies and outcomes of these trials, serving as indispensable tools for healthcare professionals in designing and prescribing treatments. However, the overwhelming volume of CTRs (e.g., exceeding 400,000 and proliferating) presents a challenge for comprehensive literature assessment when developing treatments (Bastian et al., 2010). Natural Language Inference (NLI) (Bowman et al., 2015) emerges as a promising avenue for large-scale interpretation and retrieval of medical evidence bridging recent findings to facilitate personalized care (DeYoung et al., 2020; Sutton et al., 2020). The SemEval 2024 Task 2 on the Natural Language Inference for Clinical Trials (NLI4CT) (Jullien et al., 2024) centers around annotating statements extracted from breast cancer CTRs and determining the inference relation between these statements and corresponding sections of the CTRs, such as Eligibility criteria, Intervention, Results, and Adverse events. By systematically evaluating and targeting various aspects of reasoning, including numerical, vocabulary, syntax, and semantic reasoning, the task aims to investigate Large Language Models (LLMs)’ consistency and faithful reasoning capabilities. In this paper, we investigate the performance of Gemini Pro (Team et al., 2023), GPT-3.5 (Brown et al., 2020), Flan-T5 (Longpre et al., 2023), and several pre-trained language models (PLMs) trained on biomedical datasets, including BioLinkBERT (Yasunaga et al., 2022), SciBERT (Beltagy et al., 2019), ClinicalBERT (Huang et al., 2019). We conducted comprehensive evaluations of Gemini Pro and GPT-3.5, employing the Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) framework (Lewis et al., 2020), integrating Tree of Thoughts (ToT) reasoning (Yao et al., 2023) to facilitate multiple reasoning paths. Our experiments involved applying various instruction templates to guide the generation process, and these templates were refined through a comparison of the labels within the training dataset against those generated by the models. The PLMs were trained on the provided training dataset, while the Flan-T5 model was assessed under zero-shot conditions. Gemini Pro emerged as the top-performing model among all the experimented models, achieving an F1 score of 0.69, with consistency and faithfulness scores of 0.71 and 0.90, respectively, on the official test dataset. Notably, a comparative analysis between GPT-3.5 and Gemini Pro revealed limitations in GPT-3.5’s performance, particularly in instances requiring numerical reasoning. For a detailed examination of such instances, please refer to Appendix A, where an example showcases GPT-3.5’s accurate inference yet inadequate conclusion. The code to reproduce the experiments mentioned in this paper is readily accessible.

We conducted zero-shot evaluations of Gemini Pro and GPT-3.5 using the Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) framework (Lewis et al., 2020) and integrated Tree of Thoughts (ToT) reasoning (Yao et al., 2023) to facilitate multiple reasoning paths. trips_llama3.polished_text: Monarch caterpillars rely exclusively on milkweed plants for food, and female butterflies carefully lay their eggs on the plants to ensure their larvae have a readily available food source. To find Monarch caterpillars, you can either plant milkweed in your yard or search for overgrown land in your area where milkweed plants are already growing. The Asclepias syriaca variety of milkweed, also known as common milkweed, features a stalk with broad, oval-shaped leaves, while the Asclepias incarnata variety has narrow, lance-shaped leaves and clusters of vibrant pink or purple flowers. Milkweed plants are easily identifiable when in bloom, boasting a distinctive star-shaped flower arrangement and emitting a sweet, fragrant scent in the evening hours, which attracts pollinators like monarch butterflies. Milkweed thrives in areas with disturbed ground, such as roadsides, bike paths, railroad tracks, pastures, parks, and overgrown gardens, typically requiring full sun and well-drained soil to grow. Before searching for milkweed plants, familiarize yourself with the different varieties and their characteristics by conducting an online search and consulting a plant identification guide. Starting in late spring, when the flowers first begin to bloom, it's essential to regularly monitor the plant throughout the summer to ensure its health and the well-being of any Monarch eggs or caterpillars. Monarch eggs are a bright, rounded yellow, about the size of a pencil tip, and are usually found on the underside of a leaf, often with a subtle sheen to them. Female monarchs typically lay a single egg on each milkweed plant, carefully selecting a spot with the right amount of sunlight and moisture to optimize the egg's chances of survival. Monarch eggs hatch within 4 to 5 days, during which time they are sensitive to temperature and humidity fluctuations, requiring a stable environment with temperatures between 65-75°F (18-24°C) and humidity levels of 50-60%. Newly-hatched caterpillars are approximately the size of a grain of rice, featuring smooth bodies with faint black, yellow, and white stripes, while older caterpillars exhibit the same distinct stripes but are larger, growing up to 1-1.5 inches (2.5-3.8 cm) before transforming into a butterfly. To protect fragile Monarch eggs or newly-hatched larvae, it's best to leave them on the leaf, but if handling the milkweed is necessary, gently pluck off the leaf containing the egg, taking care not to touch or damage the eggs. Taking the entire milkweed stalk will provide an abundance of food for hungry caterpillars, but gathering a few leaves can also offer a nutritious snack. When inspecting the plant, be sure to check the entire stalk to ensure it's not hiding other insects or their eggs, such as aphids, whiteflies, or spider mites, which can harm the milkweed plant and the Monarch caterpillars. If you encounter an unexpected insect, carefully brush it away or remove the leaf containing the egg, taking care not to damage the milkweed plant. To keep the milkweed stalk fresh, wrap the end in damp paper towels, then in aluminum foil, and store it in a cool, dry place until ready for use. Alternatively, you can store the milkweed stalk in a foam floral tube, cutting the tube to the right size and placing the stalk inside. To maintain the milkweed's freshness, place a few drops of water on a paper towel, then position it in the bottom of a small container, such as a glass jar or a food storage container, and cover it with a lid featuring mesh or holes to allow air circulation. The water on the paper towel will help keep the milkweed leaf from drying out, allowing you to safely wait to move the larvae until they're about 4-5 days old, at which point they will begin to crawl. Once the caterpillars are 4-5 days old and approximately 1 inch (2.5 cm) long, they'll be ready to transition to their main enclosure, where they can feed on milkweed leaves and grow into healthy, thriving caterpillars. If a caterpillar is crawling on a leaf, you can pick up the entire leaf and move it to a new enclosure, taking care not to touch or damage the caterpillar. If the caterpillar is on the bottom or side of the container, gently pick it up with your fingers to move it, taking care not to squish or harm the caterpillar. By hatching the eggs in a small container, you can closely monitor their progress and ensure the caterpillars remain healthy and thriving. When raising multiple generations of caterpillars, having a separate container for hatching eggs helps prevent the spread of illness, as you can only transfer healthy caterpillars to the larger enclosure. If you're concerned about damaging the larvae during transfer, lightly moisten the bristles of an artist's paintbrush, then slide each caterpillar onto the brush to safely transfer it, taking care not to touch or harm the caterpillar.

llama3.polished_text:
**Raising Monarch Caterpillars: A Step-by-Step Guide**

The majestic Monarch butterfly undergoes a remarkable transformation from egg to caterpillar to winged adult. To successfully raise Monarch caterpillars, it's essential to understand their life cycle and provide the right environment. Here's a comprehensive guide to help you find, raise, and care for these incredible creatures.

**Locating Milkweed Plants**

Monarch caterpillars exclusively feed on milkweed plants, which are the only host plants for their larvae. To find milkweed, either plant it in your yard or explore overgrown areas such as roadsides, bike paths, railroad tracks, pastures, parks, or overgrown gardens. Milkweed plants can grow up to 3 feet tall, with broad leaves and a distinctive star-shaped flower. If you're unsure about the plant's identity, consult a plant identification guide or search online for pictures.

**Identifying Monarch Eggs and Caterpillars**

Monarch eggs are yellow, round, and about the size of a pencil tip, usually found on the underside of milkweed leaves. Typically, there's only one egg per leaf, and a female monarch may lay only one egg on each plant. If you miss the eggs, you may spot newly hatched caterpillars, which are about the size of a grain of rice and have smooth bodies with faint black, yellow, and white stripes.

**Caring for Monarch Eggs and Caterpillars**

To protect the fragile Monarch eggs or newly hatched larvae, gently snap the milkweed stalk or pluck off the leaf containing the egg. Carry the plant back to your home, and place it in a small container with moist paper towels and aluminum foil or foam floral tubes to keep the stalk fresh. For caterpillars already hatched, you can move them directly to their permanent enclosure.

**Hatching Eggs and Transferring Caterpillars**

To hatch the eggs, place the milkweed leaf with the egg in a small container with a lid made of mesh or a hole-covered lid to allow air circulation. Add a few drops of water to the paper towel to keep the leaf from drying out. Wait for 4-5 days, and once the caterpillars emerge, they'll get their food and water by eating the milkweed leaves. You can safely wait to move the larvae until they're about 4-5 days old, when they'll be around 1 inch long.

**Transferring Caterpillars**

When the caterpillars are ready to move, gently pick them up with a moistened artist's paintbrush or your fingers if they're on a leaf. Move them to their main enclosure, and ensure they have enough milkweed leaves to eat. Keep a close eye on their progress, and if you're raising multiple generations, separate containers for hatching eggs will help prevent the spread of illness.

**Tips and Precautions**

* Before handling Monarch eggs or caterpillars, wash your hands to prevent the transfer of bacteria or other contaminants.
* Avoid disturbing the eggs or caterpillars excessively, as this can cause stress and potentially harm them.
* Keep the milkweed plant fresh by adding water to the paper towels and changing them regularly.
* Monitor the caterpillars' health and behavior, and isolate any that appear ill or injured.
* Release the adult butterflies into the wild, ideally in an area with an abundance of milkweed plants, to ensure their survival and continuation of the Monarch life cycle.

By following these steps and tips, you'll be well on your way to successfully raising Monarch caterpillars and witnessing their incredible transformation into majestic butterflies.

Carry a cell phone with you in case of an emergency, and remember to keep it close, so you can quickly call for help if needed, such as in the event of a heart issue or other medical concern. Following a heart attack, it's essential to avoid strenuous activity for four to six weeks to allow your heart time to heal, and to reduce the risk of further complications. It typically takes about six weeks for your heart to recover enough for moderate to heavy exercise, regardless of your pre-heart attack fitness level, which is often a good indicator of your overall cardiovascular health. During the recovery period, avoid activities that can put excessive strain on your heart, such as heavy lifting, vacuuming, running, or other high-impact exercises, which can help reduce the risk of further complications. As you progress, increase your exercise time and intensity gradually, but avoid anaerobic exercise, which can be too strenuous for your heart, and focus on low-impact activities that are easier on the cardiovascular system. You may experience muscle soreness in your legs and arms after starting a new exercise program, but this should subside as your body adapts to the demands of regular exercise, and you can reduce the risk of injury by listening to your body and taking regular breaks. However, it's essential to note that if muscle soreness is severe or painful during exercise, you should stop immediately and consult your doctor, as this can be a sign of a more serious underlying issue. Regular strength training can also reduce the risk of muscle wasting and inactivity, which can help improve overall health and well-being. While lifting weights or using resistance bands, avoid holding your breath, as this can increase pressure in your chest and put additional strain on your heart, and focus on controlled and slow movements. Research has shown that prolonged sitting can undo the positive effects of exercise, which can reduce the risk of chronic diseases and improve overall health, and to minimize the risks of prolonged sitting, you can take regular breaks to move around and stretch. Here's the polished text:

**Exercising Safely After a Heart Attack**

Before starting any exercise program after a heart attack, it's essential to consult with your doctor and obtain their permission. With their clearance, you can begin stretching in the hospital to prepare your body for physical activity. To maximize the benefits of stretching, aim to do it at least once a day. Remember to relax, breathe deeply, and focus on smooth movements.

When stretching, keep your joints slightly bent and avoid locking them, as this can lead to injuries. Additionally, avoid bouncing your muscles and instead, hold each stretch for 10 to 30 seconds. Repeat each stretch three to four times.

**The Importance of Stretching**

Stretching improves flexibility, making it easier to perform various exercises and activities. It also enhances balance and reduces muscle tension. Although stretching doesn't directly improve muscle strength or heart efficiency, it's an essential component of a post-heart attack exercise program.

**A Walking Program**

Regardless of your pre-heart attack fitness level, your exercise program should start with a walking program. Begin with a three-minute walking warm-up, then gradually increase your pace to a moderate level where you're breathing heavier than usual but can still hold a conversation. Aim to walk for approximately 5 minutes at this pace. Each day, add about one or two minutes to your walk until you're walking 30 minutes daily.

**Safety Precautions**

For the first few weeks, it's recommended to walk with a partner, stay close to home, and carry a cell phone in case of emergencies. Avoid strenuous activities, such as heavy lifting, vacuuming, or sudden bursts of movement, during the four to six weeks following your heart attack. Your heart needs time to heal, and excessive physical activity can exacerbate the risk of complications.

**Gradual Progression**

As your body adapts to physical activity, you can gradually increase the intensity and duration of your workouts. However, avoid anaerobic exercise, such as high-intensity interval training, until your doctor clears you for more demanding activities. Expect some muscle soreness, especially in your legs and arms, but this should subside as your body adapts to exercise.

**Incorporating Other Exercises**

Once you're comfortable walking briskly for 30 minutes daily, you can begin incorporating other exercises, such as biking, hiking, rowing, or tennis. However, it's essential to consult with your doctor before starting any new exercise program. They may recommend a strength training program to help you regain your pre-heart attack fitness level.

**Strength Training**

Strength training is a crucial component of a post-heart attack exercise program. It can help you regain your independence and reduce the risk of inactivity-related muscle wasting. You can start with light exercises, such as hand weights or resistance bands, and gradually increase the intensity and frequency of your workouts. Remember to give your muscles time to recover between sessions, aiming for at least 48 hours of rest between each strength training session.

**Maintaining Activity Levels**

To maximize the benefits of exercise, it's essential to remain active throughout the day. Aim to break up your sedentary periods with short walks, stretches, or light movements every 30 minutes. This can be as simple as getting up to drink water, use the bathroom, or walk around the room.

**Encouraging Movement**

To increase your activity levels, try these tips:

*   Walk around while on the phone or stand instead of sitting
*   Place your water glass across the room to encourage you to get up every 30 minutes
*   Organize your space to promote movement and activity throughout the day

If necessary, use a steamer to smooth out any wrinkles. For hand-washed garments, gently push out any excess water and lay the garment out on a flat surface to dry. Losing weight requires a decrease in overall body weight, which can be achieved by reducing daily caloric intake.  Decreasing your total daily calories by about 500 calories daily is a generally recommended approach, resulting in approximately 1 pound of weight loss per week.  However, cutting out too many calories may lead to slower weight loss and potential nutrition deficiencies, as you may not be consuming the recommended amount of essential nutrients. 

To plan your daily calorie intake, consider using a food journal or journaling app to track your current calorie consumption.  Subtract 500 calories from your daily total to determine your target calorie intake for weight loss. 

Fruits and vegetables are excellent choices for weight loss, as they are low in calories and rich in fiber, vitamins, and minerals.  Incorporating half of your meals and snacks with fruits and vegetables can significantly help reduce overall calorie intake.  The recommended daily intake of fruits and vegetables is about 5 to 9 servings per day.  A serving size is approximately 1/2 cup chopped fruit or 1 small piece, while a serving of vegetables is 1 cup cooked or 2 cups of salad.

Choosing whole grains over refined grains can provide more fiber and essential nutrients.  When selecting grain-based foods, opt for 100% whole grains, such as 100% whole wheat pasta, whole grain bread, brown rice, whole grain oats, quinoa, or barley.  Refined carbohydrates, made with white flour or overly processed, offer limited nutritional benefits.

Fiber not only slows the digestive process but also keeps you feeling full for a longer period.  This allows your body time to absorb nutrients.  Lean protein is essential for any diet, especially for weight loss.  The required amount of protein depends on factors such as activity level and weight.  Lean protein helps you feel satisfied longer, making it a key component of a weight loss diet. 

Include a 3-4 oz serving of protein-rich food at two meals or snacks.  This serving size is similar to the size of an adult palm or a deck of cards.  Consider incorporating low-fat dairy, seafood, lean beef, poultry, eggs, legumes, and tofu into your diet.

Staying hydrated is vital for maintaining bodily functions and healthy skin.  Aim to consume at least eight 8-oz glasses (about 2 liters) of hydrating fluids daily.  Some individuals may require up to 13 glasses (3 liters) daily, depending on their weight, gender, and activity level.  Drinking water helps control appetite, as thirst and dehydration can be mistaken for hunger.  Opt for water and unsweetened beverages over sugary drinks like juice, sweetened coffee drinks, and soda, as they are high in empty calories.

trips_llama3.polished_text: Over the past decade, natural language processing models have revolutionized the field of artificial intelligence, transforming how computers understand and generate language by enabling more accurate and nuanced analysis of complex language structures. ChatGPT is a prime example of how AI technology has become increasingly important in generating human-like responses to a wide range of problems, including business-related ones, by leveraging its advanced capabilities in natural language understanding and generation. These advancements have significant implications for the financial industry, where failing to analyze vast amounts of regulatory data and policies can result in costly regulatory violations and severe reputational damage. Indeed, Natural Language Processing (NLP) has gained traction in financial regulation as a solution for managing and interpreting complex regulatory information, which can have a direct impact on the bottom line of financial institutions. The ability to effectively process and analyze large amounts of regulatory text is crucial for compliance officers, risk managers, and other financial professionals, as it enables them to make informed decisions and avoid costly mistakes. However, traditional methods of automatic text processing, including keyword searches and dictionaries, are both inefficient and costly, requiring system experts to design dictionaries on a case-by-case basis, which can lead to protracted and costly implementation timelines. Moreover, they are also prone to errors due to lack of coverage, which can expose users to costly regulatory violations and reputational damage. Modern NLP techniques have emerged in recent years, mostly based on deep neural networks and after the seminal breakthrough by Vaswani, Shazeer, Parmar, Uszkoreit, Jones, Gomez, Kaiser, and Polosukhin, who incorporated the attention mechanism to learn latent semantic links between words in a sentence more accurately, leading to significant improvements in language understanding and generation. These improvements, along with orders of magnitude increases in the availability of datasets and computational power, have led to the development of large language models (LLMs), a type of model known for its ability to achieve general-purpose language understanding and generation, such as OpenAI's GPT (used in ChatGPT), Meta's LLaMa, or Google's PaLM. One may however wonder whether LLMs are actually required for simple NLP tasks, such as semantic search, especially due to their costs, instead of free open resources, which can have a direct impact on the bottom line of organizations. In the present work, we perform a semantic search applied to laws and regulations using a domain adaptation technique with limited data, bearing in mind the limited available resources of small and medium enterprises, which can have a significant impact on their ability to compete in the market. We also recall the historical NLP approaches and explain the leading concepts in this field, which can have a direct impact on the development of new NLP techniques and models. In particular, we focus on semantic search, which naturally leads to the encoding concepts of a sentence, which can have a significant impact on the ability to understand and analyze complex language structures. We thus aim to fill the gap between well-known NLP concepts and the mathematical frameworks behind, which can have a direct impact on the development of new NLP techniques and models. This paper is organized as follows: Section 2 is a short historical review on encoding methods of a sentence into a mathematical object as well as key machine learning advances, which can have a direct impact on the development of new NLP techniques and models. In Section 3, we describe the task of semantic textual similarity, the different techniques at hand, and illustrate them with pseudo codes, which can have a direct impact on the ability to understand and analyze complex language structures. In Section 4, we apply these techniques concretely to financial regulation problems to improve semantic search matching, which can have a significant impact on the ability to comply with regulations and avoid costly violations. Section 5 draws conclusions from this analysis, which can have a direct impact on the development of new NLP techniques and models and the ability to apply them in real-world applications.

Over the past decade, modern natural language processing (NLP) models have revolutionized the field of artificial intelligence, transforming how computers understand and generate language. One key example of this advancement is ChatGPT, which showcases the increasing importance of AI technology in generating human-like responses to a wide range of problems, including those in the business sector. This progress has significant implications for the financial industry, where vast amounts of regulatory data and policies must be analyzed and understood to comply with laws and regulations.

Indeed, NLP has gained traction in financial regulation as a solution for managing and interpreting complex regulatory information. The ability to effectively process and analyze large amounts of regulatory text is crucial for compliance officers, risk managers, and other financial professionals. However, traditional methods of automatic text processing, including keyword searches and dictionaries, are both inefficient and costly to implement. They require significant expertise to design and maintain, and are prone to errors due to lack of coverage, which can expose users to costly regulatory violations.

In recent years, modern NLP techniques have emerged, largely based on deep neural networks, following the seminal breakthrough by Vaswani et al. [1], who incorporated the attention mechanism to improve the learning of latent semantic links between words in a sentence. These advancements, combined with the increasing availability of datasets and computational power, have led to the development of large language models (LLMs), such as OpenAI's GPT (used in ChatGPT), Meta's LLaMa, and Google's PaLM. These models are capable of achieving general-purpose language understanding and generation. However, their high costs and complexity have led some to question whether they are necessary for simple NLP tasks, such as semantic search.

In this work, we address this question by applying a domain adaptation technique with limited data to perform semantic search on laws and regulations, taking into account the limited resources available to small and medium enterprises. We also provide a historical review of NLP approaches and explain the leading concepts in this field. Specifically, we focus on semantic search, which naturally leads to the encoding concepts of a sentence. Our goal is to fill the gap between well-known NLP concepts and the mathematical frameworks behind them.

This paper is organized as follows: Section 2 provides a short historical review of encoding methods for a sentence into a mathematical object, as well as key machine learning advances. In Section 3, we describe the task of semantic textual similarity, the different techniques at hand, and illustrate them with pseudo codes. In Section 4, we apply these techniques concretely to financial regulation problems to improve semantic search matching. Finally, Section 5 draws conclusions from this analysis.

Last week, I experienced a unique and unexpected event while driving home. As I was approaching my destination, I noticed an old dog attempting to cross the road. Its slow and labored movements gave away its age, and it was astonishing that it wasn't wearing a collar. My concern for its safety prompted me to jump out of the car and retrieve a collar and leash from my trunk. The dog initially seemed friendly, but it was clear that it was frightened of me, so I took a cautious approach, gently guiding it towards the side of the road. From there, I was able to carefully approach the dog and secure a collar and leash.

As I pondered what to do next, I realized that the dog had no identification and it was getting late – past 9:30 at night. Thankfully, my house was nearby, so I let the dog into my garage and provided it with some much-needed food and water. This brief respite allowed me to think clearly about my next steps.

While the dog was resting, I came up with an idea. Since it was too late to contact animal control, I had a few options. I could keep the dog overnight and arrange for its pickup in the morning, or I could attempt to walk it back home. After some consideration, I decided to try the latter, so we set off into the darkness, following the road until we were a few blocks away from my house.

As we walked, the dog began to veer off the road and into some dark alleys. I was hesitant to follow, but I didn't want to leave the dog to fend for itself. Just as we were at a crossroads, a car turned onto the street and pulled into its driveway. I thought it would be a good opportunity to ask a neighbor if they knew anything about the dog. As luck would have it, they recognized the dog and pointed me in the direction of its family's home. After an awkward but mercifully brief door-knocking session late at night, I was able to reunite the dog with its overjoyed family.

II. INTRODUCTION

The landscape of robotics is undergoing a significant transformation, characterized by the emergence of advanced robots capable of performing complex tasks in dynamic and unpredictable settings [1]. One of the most pressing challenges in this field is the development of efficient and effective path planning strategies for robots, which requires a synergy between motion planning and perception algorithms. The literature has witnessed the proliferation of various methodologies in the realm of path planning, including graph optimization path planning [2, 3, 4], heuristic-based strategies [5], and the exploration of rapidly exploring random trees (RRTs) [6, 7, 8]. Despite these advances, conventional path-planning frameworks often struggle to navigate complex environments and adapt to fluctuating environmental conditions [9, 10, 11].

The advent of large language models (LLMs), such as GPT-3.5-turbo, has introduced new capabilities, including natural language processing, question answering, and conversational dialogue. This raises the intriguing possibility of robots leveraging the vast knowledge encapsulated in such models to tackle complex tasks in the physical world. The question is: how can physical entities harness and apply the knowledge from LLMs to tasks in the tangible world?

Employing GPT-3.5-turbo for robotic path planning presents a promising avenue to overcome the limitations inherent in traditional methodologies. GPT-3.5-turbo's advanced natural language processing capabilities position it as an ideal candidate for tackling the multifaceted and dynamic challenges in robotics. Moreover, its ability to provide efficient and adaptable path-planning solutions in real-time lays a solid groundwork for future explorations in this domain.

GPT-3.5-turbo has demonstrated outstanding performance in various natural language processing tasks, including language production, question answering, and machine translation [12, 13, 14]. Its excellent accuracy and few-shot learning capabilities enable it to excel in these tasks, attributed to its capacity to identify patterns in vast amounts of data [15, 16, 17]. For instance, recent studies have demonstrated that GPT-3.5-turbo can automate the robot software's production and utilize GPT-3.5-turbo to produce code for robotic tasks in real-time [18, 19, 20]. Additionally, GPT-3.5-turbo has been shown to have the potential for human-robot interaction when utilized to generate natural language instructions for robotic manipulation tasks [21, 22, 23].

Our approach is motivated by assessing the applicability of GPT-3.5-turbo to the robotics industry's path-planning challenge. The use of GPT-3.5-turbo in robotic path planning is a fascinating topic, as it has the potential to revolutionize the sector entirely. Our method converts the robotic path planning problem into a natural language problem to provide optimized paths for robotic systems. GPT-3.5-turbo then optimizes this problem to produce the desired results. The overview of the proposed approach is shown in Fig. 1.

The key contributions of this paper are:

* We propose an LLM-powered robotic system for autonomous path planning.
* We suggest a probabilistic transformation mechanism for signal to language and back to robotic motion.
* We evaluate the performance of the proposed system with state-of-the-art path planners (A\* [2] and RRT [24]) and observe the least distance traveled and shortest planning time.
